newsitem.title: USA: American General to acquire USLife for $1.8 billion.
newsitem.headline: American General to acquire USLife for $1.8 billion.

text.p: American General Corp. will acquire USLife Corp., a rival financial services company with major life insurance operations, for $1.8 billion in stock, the companies said Thursday.
The acquisition comes amid a major consolidation in the life insurance industry and follows weeks of speculation that USLife might be a takeover candidate.
American General said it will pay $49 worth of its own common stock for each share of New York-based USLife.
American General's shares edged up 37.5 cents to $41.875, and USLife soared $5.25 to $47, both on the New York Stock Exchange.

"This merger represents the largest transaction in American General's history and is an outstanding strategic fit which offers a unique opportunity to combine two of the premier providers of life insurance and financial services in the nation," said American General Chief Executive Rober M. Devlin said in a statement.
USLIFE Chairman Gordon Crosby told investors on a tense conference call he does not expect any jobs to be eliminated as a result of the merger. "We don't anticipate any at the moment," he said.
He said there would be cost savings, that decisions about senior management of the combined company had not yet been made, and that the deal included a $48 million break up fee.
But Crosby declined to elaborate, infuriating investors and Wall Street analysts who found him was surprisingly uncooperative.
"I never heard one like that," one analyst said. "I give up on what the intention of this conference call was. If you're not at liberty to speak, why be there?" he said.

Speculation about USLife had grown in recent weeks as Crosby, its chairman for 30 years, neared the end of his term with no chance for re-election unless the board approved an extension in the age limit for directors.
Crosby, 76, who had been known for his steadfast opposition to a takeover of the company, said Thursday, "This is truly an outstanding result for both organisations."

American General is a diversified financial services company that provides retirement services, consumer loans and life insurance to nine million customers. It had 1996 sales of $10.9 billion. The company has about 15,300 employees.
USLife, also a holding company, has operations in life and health insurance and other financial services. It had 1996 sales of $1.6 billion. The company has about 2,140 employees.

Standard & Poor's Corp. said its ratings on USLIFE's debt remain under review, since Wednesday, amid concerns about the company's limited financial flexibility and surprisingly low life insurance sales in 1996.
However, the credit agency revised its implications to "developing" from negative after news of the merger.
